channel.title: Advent of Code 2023 on jverkamp.com
channel.description: Recent content in Advent of Code 2023 on jverkamp.com

item.title: Advent of Code 2023 - Testing and Timing
item.description:
A quick follow up to Advent of Code 2023: testing and timing.

It’s been bothering me a bit that I haven’t had a generic way to run tests and timing on every problem as I’m going.

So let’s fix it!

  • Testing
  • Timing
  • Summary

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 25: Graph Splitinator
item.description:
Source: Day 25: Snowverload

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 25: Snowverload
  • Part 1
    • Parsing
    • Solution 1: Brute Force
    • A dot graph
    • Solution 2: Calculate ‘heavy’ edges
    • A better N
    • Performance
  • Part 2

Part 1

Given an undirected graph, find 3 edges that split the graph into two connected components. Return the product of the component’s sizes.

item.description:
Source: Day 24: Never Tell Me The Odds

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 24: Never Tell Me The Odds
  • Part 1
    • Parsing and Types
    • XY Intersections
    • Solution
  • Part 2
    • Solution 1: Brute Force
    • Solution 2: Using Z3

Part 1

Given a set of 3D vectors (origin + velocity), count how many times the vectors would intersect. Ignore the Z-coordinate for this part; the collisions do not have to be at the same time.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 22: Block Dropinator
item.description:
Source: Day 22: Sand Slabs

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Solution
    • Edit 1, Now with faster dropping
  • Part 2
    • Trying other datatypes
    • Remove debugging
    • Edit 1, Using fast drop
  • Performance

Part 1

Given a series of 3D blocks, allow them to fall until the simulation is stable. Any cube of a block is sufficient to support another block, ignore rotations etc.

How many blocks are not the sole supporter for any other block?

Given a(n infinite) grid of walls #, count how many points can be reached by exactly 64 steps from a starting point.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 20: Flip-Flopinator
item.description:
Source: Day 20: Pulse Propagation

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 20: Pulse Propagation
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Solution
  • Part 2
    • Solution 1: Brute Force
    • A pretty picture
    • Solution 2: Least common multiple
  • Performance

Part 1

Simulate a virtual circuit with high and low pulses and four kinds of chips:

  • Broadcast - Re-transmit all pulses
  • Flip-flops - On a low pulse, toggle internal state; if it was on, send high; otherwise send low
  • Conjunction - Remember input from each attached module; if all inputs were high, send a low, otherwise send high
  • Output - Do nothing; just receive pulses

Count the product of low and high pulses sent after 1000 low inputs to broadcaster.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 19: Assembly Lininator
item.description:
Source: Day 19: Aplenty

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 19: Aplenty
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Simulation
  • Part 2
    • Brute Force
    • Ranges
  • Performance

Part 1

You are given a series of parts with 4 ratings as such:

{x=787,m=2655,a=1222,s=2876}

In addition, you are given a series of rules describing a graph as such:

px{a<2006:qkq,m>2090:A,rfg}

In this example, if you are at the node px, if a < 2006, move to qkq. Otherwise, if m > 2090 move to A. If no other case matches, the last defaults to rfg.

A and R are special cases for accept and reject.

Calculate the sum of sum of all four ratings for all nodes that end at Accept.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 16: Reflectinator
item.description:
Source: Day 16: The Floor Will Be Lava

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 16: The Floor Will Be Lava
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance
  • Grid
    • Implementation
    • Point
    • Bounds
  • Edit 1, Adding to_string and to_image for Grid

Part 1

You are given a grid of mirrors (|-\/) and empty space (.).

Diagonal mirrors just relect the light.

The horizontal and vertical mirrors are splitters, light hitting them head on (like >|) will split to go both directions. Light hitting edge on will just go through it.

Starting in the top left going East, how many total tiles will a light beam illuminate?

Source: Day 15: Lens Library

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 15: Lens Library
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Hash each input (comma separated) with h(v, c) = (v + c) * 17 (modulo 256 / as a byte). Sum these values.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 12: Question Markinator
item.description:
Source: Day 12: Hot Springs

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 12: Hot Springs
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Solution
    • Cleaning up
  • Part 2
    • (Almost) Brute Force
    • Caching
    • A choice of map
    • Rewriting it with types
  • Performance

Part 1

Given a sequence of #.? as on, off, and unknown and a sequence of group sizes, determine how many possible arrangements there are that match the given groups.

More specifically, if you have ???.## 1,2 you need a single # and a set of two ##, there are three possibilities: #...###, .#..###, and ..#.###.

item.description:
Source: Day 11: Cosmic Expansion

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 11: Cosmic Expansion
  • Part 1
    • Parsing
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Read a grid of # (stars) and . (empty space). For each completely empty line or row, add another. Calculate the sum of the Manhattan distances between all pairs of stars.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 10: Pipinator
item.description:
Source: Day 10: Pipe Maze

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 10: Pipe Maze
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Iterating
    • Solution
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

You are given as input an ASCII art pipe diagram with straight pipes |-, right angle turns LJ7F, ground ., and a start tile S.

The start tile will be part of a loop of pipes.

Find the distance to the furthest connected pipe segment from S (or half the length of the loop).

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 9: Stackinator
item.description:
Source: Day 9: Mirage Maintenance

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 9: Mirage Maintenance
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Given a list of terms, repeatedly calculate the differences of terms until these differences are 0. So:

0 3 6 9 12 15
 3 3 3 3 3
 0 0 0 0

Calculate the sum of next terms for each sequence (18 for this one).

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 8: Mazinator
item.description:
Source: Day 8: Haunted Wasteland

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 8: Haunted Wasteland
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Solution
  • Part 2
    • Brute Force
    • Detecting Cycles
  • Performance

Part 1

Given a (repeated) sequence of moves (L for left and R for right) and a directed graph where each node has two neighbors (left and right), count how many total steps it takes to get from the node AAA to the node ZZZ. The sequence of moves can (and will) need to repeat.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 7: Pokinator
item.description:
Source: Day 7: Camel Cards

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 7: Camel Cards
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Solving the Problem
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Simulate a limited poker game with no suits and break otherwise tied hands lexicographically (AAAA2 beats AKAAA) because the the hands are both four of a kind, the first cards are both A, but the second A beats the K. It doesn’t matter that the first hand’s off card was a 2

Order all hands then calculate the sum of the ordering of hands (1 for best etc) times the bet for each.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 6: Racinator
item.description:
Source: Day 6: Wait For It

Full solution for today (spoilers!)

  • Source: Day 6: Wait For It
  • Part 1
    • Types and Parsing
    • Initial Brute Force Solution
  • Part 2
  • (Premature) Optimization

Part 1

Simulate charging up race boats with the behavior that waiting X seconds to start means you move at X units per second. Given time allowed and a target distance, determine how many (integer) numbers of seconds will beat the target distance.

You are given a set of initial values (seeds) and a series of range maps (where a range of numbers src..src+len maps to dst..dst+len). Apply each range map in tur, return the lowest resulting value.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 4: Scratchinator
item.description:
Source: Day 4: Scratchcards

Full solution for today (spoilers!). Note: I did slightly change my solutions template after writing this blog post, so the final solution is structured slightly differently than the code in this post. The functionality itself hasn’t changed.

  • Source: Day 4: Scratchcards
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Simulate scratchcards. Given a list of winning numbers and guessed numbers, count how many guessed numbers are in the winning list. Your score is 1, 2, 4, 8, … for 1, 2, 3, 4, … matching numbers.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 3: Gearinator
item.description:
Source: Day 3: Gear Ratios

Full solution for today (spoilers!). Note: I did slightly change my solutions template after writing this blog post, so the final solution is structured slightly differently than the code in this post. The functionality itself hasn’t changed.

  • Source: Day 3: Gear Ratios
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Take as input a 2D grid of numbers or symbols (. represents empty space). Numbers will be 1 or more digits written horizontally which should be concatenated (.467* is the number 467 followed by the symbol *).

Sum all numbers that are adjacent (including diagonally) to at least one symbol.

item.title: AoC 2023 Day 2: Playinator
item.description:
Source: Day 2: Cube Conundrum

Full solution for today (spoilers!). Note: I did slightly change my solutions template after writing this blog post, so the final solution is structured slightly differently than the code in this post. The functionality itself hasn’t changed.

  • Source: Day 2: Cube Conundrum
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Performance

Part 1

Play a game where you have some number of red, green, and blue dice in a cup, which you draw and roll (without replacement). Which game is possible with only 12 red, 13 gree, and 14 blue cubes?

Input will look like: Game 1: 3 blue, 4 red; 1 red, 2 green, 6 blue; 2 green

item.description:

Part 1

Given a list of alphanumeric strings, find the first and last digit on each line (they may be the same). Concatenate each pair and sum them.

item.title: Advent of Code 2023
item.description:
Another year, another Advent of Code.

Like last year, we’re doing Rust. I’ve really grown to love the language since last year… and hopefully I’ve learned a bit more about how to write more ‘proper’ Rust. I know I had some issues last year. Functional… but it could be better.

Let’s see how it goes!

For full solutions, as always, I post to GitHub (including previous years and possibly some I haven’t written up yet): jpverkamp/advent-of-code
